ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Journal Article Explores New Hypothesis for Increasing Evolvability
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Joel and Ken, Congrats on the excellent paper. I enjoyed it. Congrats also on the nice press coverage. My weekly KurzweilAI.net email this week has your

From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] New Journal Article Explores New Hypothesis for Increasing Evolvability
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=BCaU6QJnjfrIxrsY8RrRyHFdXUzfJqRf2LyIeQFBjPijlkwOj4sL
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_84B27BA5-6EE8-4454-A821-7DF45EE2CD1D
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Joel and Ken,

Congrats on the excellent paper. I enjoyed it. 

Congr=
ats also on the nice press coverage. My weekly KurzweilAI.net email this we=
ek has your article featured!

http://www.kurzweilai.net/a-new-spin-on-orig=
ins-of-evolvability-survival-of-the-evolvable?utm_source=3DKurzweilAI+Weekl=
y+Newsletter&utm_campaign=3Df2d8f1bc7d-UA-946742-1&utm_medium=3Demail&utm_t=
erm=3D0_147a5a48c1-f2d8f1bc7d-282027325

(nice office Ken)

I have a three =
questions, two higher-level and one pedantic.

1) You write: "Thus if the a=
ssumption of evolvability=92s heritability holds, then such founder effects=
 in establishing new niches may yield a persistent bias towards increasing =
evolvability =96 even in the absence of adaptive competition between organi=
sms."

My guess is that this assumption doesn't hold across many generation=
s in the scenario you outline. Your model, especially the limited capacity =
model, awards permanent winner status to the founder (if I understand it co=
rrectly), but obviously that does not happen in nature. In nature, once a n=
iche is founded, there is no pressure (for those orgs staying in the niche)=
 to retain their evolvability (assuming a relatively static environment). A=
s my mutation rates paper shows (http://goo.gl/I8r40), once a population is=
 on a local fitness peak there is a strong pressure to lower the mutation r=
ate (which in your model is the same thing as evolvability). Offspring of t=
he founder with lower mutRates/evolvability would have higher average fitne=
ss than offsprings with the original, elevated mutRate/evolvability, thus l=
eading to a lowering of mutation rates/evolvability across generations. If =
that is right, it would erase this founder effect and eliminate the appeara=
nce of evolvability even when averaging across niches, no? In other words, =
you'd only see this elevation in newly occupied niches, which would be a sm=
all fraction of the total number of niches after millennia. In short, while=
 I agree with this clever demonstration that evolvability can increase with=
out selection, it could be the case that selection itself eliminates this s=
ort of evolvability effect, leaving us still searching for how nature gener=
ates and maintains evolvability. You could test this by trying your same ex=
periments in the abstract model, but on a rugged fitness landscape (e.g. Ra=
strigin), and I'm confident you'd see the mutation rate/evolvability go to =
near zero (that's effectively the exact experiment I did in my PLoS Comp Bi=
o paper). That result would jive with your belief that selection may actual=
ly preclude evolvability and be a hinderance to open-ended evolution, but i=
t may also mean that the effect you point out is not a major explanation of=
 evolvability in the natural world where selection is a powerful force. I h=
ope I don't come across as someone trying to diminish the importance of you=
r work; instead I am trying to understand how far I can extrapolate it to t=
he natural world. 

2) You repeatedly mention that you are using one of man=
y definitions of evolvability, defining it as synonymous with phenotypic va=
riability. I got the impression that you were arguing for one definition of=
 evolvability from a set of common ones, perhaps even a less common one. I =
usually think of evolvability as certain kinds of phenotypic variability (e=
.g. evolution produces the subset of variants that have a higher average fi=
tness than the entire set of possible variants). What would the implication=
s for your paper be if you adopted that (I believe more common) definition =
of evolvability? Are there other major definitions of evolvability that you=
 encountered in your literature search? If so, does adopting them change th=
e interpretation of your paper?

3) Here's the pedantic question. In your a=
bstract model (not the limited capacity model, the unlimited one), I assume=
 that mutations can move an org one step in any direction, including back t=
oward the center. Given that, shouldn't a higher mutation rate just mean a =
larger variance around the origin? Random walks, after all, still have an a=
verage location of their starting point. If so, I agree that the  far-flung=
 niches would disproportionately have high evolvability, but I would also e=
xpect to see greater variance in evolvability in the central niches than th=
e distant niches...but that's the opposite of Fig. 3. If each organism is o=
n a random walk, and higher evolvability means a faster pace, then you woul=
d have lots of these faster organisms traversing back and forth across the =
center too, but you don't see any of those orgs in Fig. 3. I am sure I am m=
isunderstanding something, and it is probably trivial, but I just wanted to=
 ask in case my misunderstanding is making me not fully appreciate your wor=
k. 

Congratulations again. I'm still thinking about all of the implication=
s of the paper. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Sc=
ience
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Apr 26, 20=
13, at 7:04 PM, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:

> 
> 
> Hi Martin,
> 
=
> Your illustration (http://www.martinpyka.de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/ev=
olvability.png) is very helpful in teasing apart how undirected genetic mut=
ations (interpreting the isocloud on the left as the genetic space) can yet=
 produce structured phenotypic changes (interpreting the image on the right=
 as the corresponding changes in the phenotype) through an evolvable genoty=
pe-phenotype map. 
> 
> Thanks for taking the effort to create the image, w=
hich also clarifies how canalization can work to potentially enhance evolva=
bility. I am learning much from this discussion too.
> 
> Joel
> 
> --- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "martin_pyka" <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Joe=
l,
> > 
> > thanks for your fast response which addressed exactly my inquir=
y. 
> > 
> > First, I want to clarify that even if evolvability can reach a=
 maximum the conclusion of your paper is correct that it can emerge without=
 any pressure for adaptation in the individuals. In this regard, my questio=
n whether a maximum of evolvability exists was more of general nature.
> > =

> > > The way I think about it currently is that perhaps there is no ultim=
ate tension, and that evolvability can generally increase without limit. Th=
e reason is that canalization of low-level mechanisms can act to increase e=
volvability. For example, many of the mechanisms behind development are hea=
vily conserved, but can generate much phenotypic variability through being =
combined and modulated in various ways. In other words, modulating conserve=
d features of development gives evolution higher-level levers that enable s=
mall genetic changes to be amplified and have a large meaningful phenotypic=
 effect. Thus through continued evolution of the genotype/phenotype map, pe=
rhaps evolvability can continually increase (through exploiting canalizatio=
n of lower-level mechanisms to generate increasingly high-level features).
=
> > 
> > Yep, when I read this I noted that this is actually also my opinio=
n about generative encodings. From this perspective, I would also assume th=
at evolvability can continuously increase in the sense that the genome can =
become more powerful (or more flexible) in generating new meaningful phenot=
ypes. Maybe my implicit assumption was not correct that evolvability in a p=
henotype map could be depicted as iso-oriented point-cloud:
> > 
> > left i=
mage in http://www.martinpyka.de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.pn=
g
> > 
> > According to this illustration, increased evolvability would inc=
rease the size of the point cloud. I think I had this picture in mind when =
I argued in my previous post that evolvability cannot increase infinitely b=
ecause genotype-phenotype mappings should become instable when a certain de=
gree of evolvability has been reached. However, maybe a 2d-depiction of the=
 evolvable phenotype-space would rather look like in the right image (I am =
sorry for my poor artwork). Through canalization, not all phenotypes in the=
 2d-space are evolvable but evolvability itself can still increase!?
> > 
>=
 > Maybe, both pictures can also illustrate what canalization means. The le=
ft picture could depict all possible points in the genotype space that can =
be reached through mutation and recombination and the right image all possi=
ble points in the phenotype space that can be generated from it. While each=
 bit in the (2d)-genotype has equal probability of been mutated, in canaliz=
ed encodings only a well-ordered subspace of phenotypes can be reached.
> >=
 
> > Thank you for this inspiring discussion. :-) I enjoy thinking about h=
ow all this fits together.
> > 
> > Best,
> > Martin
> >
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_84B27BA5-6EE8-4454-A821-7DF45EE2CD1D

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

<br><div><=

Hi Martin,<br>
<br>
Your illustration (<a href=
=3D"http://www.martinpyka.de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png">h=
ttp://www.martinpyka.de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png</a>) is=
 very helpful in teasing apart how undirected genetic mutations (interpreti=
ng the isocloud on the left as the genetic space) can yet produce structure=
d phenotypic changes (interpreting the image on the right as the correspond=
ing changes in the phenotype) through an evolvable genotype-phenotype map. =
<br>
<br>
Thanks for taking the effort to create the image, which also clar=
ifies how canalization can work to potentially enhance evolvability. I am l=
earning much from this discussion too.<br>

Joel<br>

 <martin.pyka@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hi Joel,<br>
> <br>
&g=
t; thanks for your fast response which addressed exactly my inquiry. <br>
&=
gt; <br>
> First, I want to clarify that even if evolvability can reach =
a maximum the conclusion of your paper is correct that it can emerge withou=
t any pressure for adaptation in the individuals. In this regard, my questi=
on whether a maximum of evolvability exists was more of general nature.<br>=

> <br>
> > The way I think about it currently is that perhaps the=
re is no ultimate tension, and that evolvability can generally increase wit=
hout limit. The reason is that canalization of low-level mechanisms can act=
 to increase evolvability. For example, many of the mechanisms behind devel=
opment are heavily conserved, but can generate much phenotypic variability =
through being combined and modulated in various ways. In other words, modul=
ating conserved features of development gives evolution higher-level levers=
 that enable small genetic changes to be amplified and have a large meaning=
ful phenotypic effect. Thus through continued evolution of the genotype/phe=
notype map, perhaps evolvability can continually increase (through exploiti=
ng canalization of lower-level mechanisms to generate increasingly high-lev=
el features).<br>
> <br>
> Yep, when I read this I noted that this is=
 actually also my opinion about generative encodings. From this perspective=
, I would also assume that evolvability can continuously increase in the se=
nse that the genome can become more powerful (or more flexible) in generati=
ng new meaningful phenotypes. Maybe my implicit assumption was not correct =
that evolvability in a phenotype map could be depicted as iso-oriented poin=
t-cloud:<br>
> <br>
> left image in <a href=3D"http://www.martinpyka.=
de/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png">http://www.martinpyka.de/wp=
-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png</a><br>
> <br>
> According =
to this illustration, increased evolvability would increase the size of the=
 point cloud. I think I had this picture in mind when I argued in my previo=
us post that evolvability cannot increase infinitely because genotype-pheno=
type mappings should become instable when a certain degree of evolvability =
has been reached. However, maybe a 2d-depiction of the evolvable phenotype-=
space would rather look like in the right image (I am sorry for my poor art=
work). Through canalization, not all phenotypes in the 2d-space are evolvab=
le but evolvability itself can still increase!?<br>
> <br>
> Maybe, b=
oth pictures can also illustrate what canalization means. The left picture =
could depict all possible points in the genotype space that can be reached =
through mutation and recombination and the right image all possible points =
in the phenotype space that can be generated from it. While each bit in the=
 (2d)-genotype has equal probability of been mutated, in canalized encoding=
s only a well-ordered subspace of phenotypes can be reached.<br>
> <br>
=
> Thank you for this inspiring discussion. :-) I enjoy thinking about ho=
w all this fits together.<br>
> <br>
> Best,<br>
> Martin<br>
